description: Test Cases for use with Google ADK adk eval

parts.text:
For Lipitor 20mg, the cheapest therapeutically equivalent option is its generic, Atorvastatin Calcium.
 Here's a comparison of the average spend per dosage unit under Medicare Part D in 2023: Lipitor (brand): $15.68
 Atorvastatin Calcium (generic): As low as $0.11 (from Marlex Pharm.) This means the generic Atorvastatin Calcium
 can be significantly cheaper. Please remember that this is a program-level average and your individual co-pay may vary.

eval_cases.eval_id: Test case 2: ritalin_10mg-Brand Name drug cheaper.

parts.text:
For Ritalin 10mg, here are the therapeutically equivalent options ranked by their average Medicare Part D spend per dosage unit in 2023:
 Ritalin (Brand-name): $1.28 per dose
 Methylphenidate (Generic from Mylan): $12.64 per dose
 Methylphenidate (Generic, overall average): $12.64 per dose
 Methylphenidate (Generic from Padagis): $12.65 per dose
 Daytrana (Brand-name Methylphenidate): $15.28 per dose
 Cotempla XR-ODT (Brand-name Methylphenidate): $16.89 per dose
 Based on the 2023 Medicare Part D data, the brand-name Ritalin 10mg tablet has the lowest average spend per dosage unit among the therapeutically equivalent options.
 Please remember that this metric reflects program-level average spend and may not directly equate to your individual co-pay.

eval_cases.eval_id: Test case 3: prozac_20mg-No Medicare Part D average spend data for its generic equivalent.

parts.text:
Prozac 20mg is a brand-name drug. Its therapeutic equivalent is Fluoxetine Hydrochloride.
 Using the latest available data from 2023, the average Medicare Part D spend per dosage unit for Prozac is $24.66.
 I could not find Medicare Part D average spend data for its generic equivalent, Fluoxetine Hydrochloride, for 2023.
 Please note that this metric is program-level and may not reflect your individual co-pay.

eval_cases.eval_id: Test case 4: vraylar_3mg-no generic therapeutic equivalent drug identified 12-14-2025.

parts.text:
Vraylar 3mg is a brand-name drug. According to the Orange Book, there are no therapeutic equivalents (generic options) for Vraylar 3mg.
 Using the latest available data from 2023, the average Medicare Part D spend per dosage unit for Vraylar is $48.81.
 Please note that this metric is program-level and may not reflect your individual co-pay.
Show me my recent drug searches

Vraylar 3mg: Vraylar 3mg (brand) has an average Medicare Part D spend of $48.81 per dose in 2023. No therapeutic equivalents (generic options) were found for Vraylar 3mg.
 prozac 20mg: Prozac 20mg (brand) has an average Medicare Part D spend of $24.66 per dose in 2023. No Medicare Part D average spend data was found for its generic equivalent, Fluoxetine Hydrochloride, for 2023.
 Ritalin 10mg: For Ritalin 10mg, the brand-name Ritalin had the lowest average Medicare Part D spend per dosage unit at $1.28 in 2023. Generic Methylphenidate options (e.g., from Mylan, Padagis) were significantly higher, ranging from $12.64 to $12.65 per dose. Other brand-name Methylphenidate products like Daytrana and Cotempla XR-ODT had even higher costs, ranging from $15.28 to $16.89 per dose. This indicates that the brand-name Ritalin 10mg tablet is currently the most cost-effective option based on Medicare Part D average spend for 2023.Lipitor 20mg: For Lipitor 20mg, the cheapest therapeutically equivalent option is its generic, Atorvastatin Calcium. Here's a comparison of the average spend per dosage unit under Medicare Part D in 2023: Lipitor (brand): $15.68. Atorvastatin Calcium (generic): As low as $0.11 (from Marlex Pharm.).
